description:
December 27, 2020. Libya: The Minister of Health of the Libyan government and a member of the Supreme Committee to Combat Corona Epidemic, Dr.Saad Akoub, issued urgent directives to all directors of monitoring, investigation and rapid response in the municipalities to conduct and implement inspection field visits to all schools to ensure the implementation of precautionary measures, with students soon to return to study, starting tomorrow.

The Minister of Health also stressed in his directives the need to confirm the state of schools ’readiness to receive students, and to implement all the precautionary measures recommended by the Supreme and Advisory Committee, with the visiting team applying the form for examining the application of precautionary measures in schools, the data of which is entered into a monitoring and investigation program to analyze The results of the visits and the suitability of schools to receive students, by filling out the forms compared to the student density in each school.
date_end_spec: The policy has an unlimited time span (e.g. recommendation to wash one's hands; passing of a legal bill)
type_sub_cat: Preschool or childcare facilities (generally for children ages 5 and below)
institution_status: Preschool or childcare facilities allowed to open with conditions
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
On March 22, 2020, Libya declared a country-wide curfew, which "is from 6 pm until 6 am," closing "all mosques at all prayer times, educational institutions, cafes, restaurants, events halls, clubs, entertainment centers, and commercial outlets" during curfew hours.

The decree also states that "curfew breakers will be liable to punishment under existing laws."

On March 30, 2020, curfew hours were extended to be from 2 pm until 7 am.

March 21, 2020: 
Nationwide curfew imposed. The Libyan Presidential Council of the Government of National Accord (GNA) has announced a curfew across Libya starting March 22 from 6.00 p.m. to 6.00 a.m. The curfew excluded security, health workers and other people involved in pharmacy services, environmental work, energy, telecommunications and cargo.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
target_who_gen: Non-essential workers (please note their occupation in the text entry where applicable)

description:

The decree also states that "curfew breakers will be liable to punishment under existing laws."

On March 22, 2020, Libya declared country-wide curfew, which "is from 6pm until 6am," closing "all mosques at all prayer times, educational institutions, cafes, restaurants, events halls, clubs, entertainment centres and commercial outlets" during curfew hours.

The decree also states that "curfew breakers will be liable to punishment under existing laws."

Update: This curfew has now been extended by another 10 days beginning from Tuesday, April 28. New curfew hours have also been announced, now from 6 pm till 6 am.

description:
On March 22, 2020, Libya declared a country-wide curfew, which "is from 6 pm until 6 am," closing "all mosques at all prayer times, educational institutions, cafes, restaurants, events halls, clubs, entertainment centers, and commercial outlets" during curfew hours.

The decree also states that "curfew breakers will be liable to punishment under existing laws."

Update: Starting May 18, The partial curfew will be extended for another 10 days. However, a full 24-hour lockdown will be imposed on throughout the days of the Eid Al-Fitr celebrations.

description:
6pm to 6am curfew set by government; 

Adapted on March 30 to 2pm to 7am and work hours limited from 9.00-12.00

Update March 22: 
The Ministry of Interior has warned that anyone who violates quarantine measures or the curfew imposed as part of the measures to prevent a coronavirus outbreak in Libya could be jailed up to six months or fined up of 200 dinars.

"Those who violate any legitimate order issued by the authorities in order to preserve public safety and health will face a punishment of one month". UPDATE: Originally no explicit mention of repercussions of curfew violators, now there is.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
compliance: Mandatory with Legal Penalties (Jail Time),Mandatory with Fines

description:
In Libya, it was announced on March 23 that "a daily curfew from 3 p.m. until 7 a.m. in all areas under the control of the LAAF. These include eastern cities, the city of Sebha in the south, and Sebratha on the western coast"

On April 20, it was announced by the Fuel Crisis Committee that drivers for fuel distribution centers and drivers of trucks delivering LPG bottled gas cylinders will be exempted from the curfew.
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description:
On May 27, 2020, A COVID-19 Rapid Response Centre has been established in Tripoli, which will be staffed by 40 doctors and 20 consultants to respond to incoming calls. The centre will be linked to all 19 established isolation and hospitalization sites and will
coordinate its work with 65 Rapid Response Teams and almost 600 health professionals.

description:
December 7 2020, Libya: On direct instructions from His Excellency the Minister of Health of the Libyan government, Dr. Saad Okoub, today morning, the committee in charge of the Ministry of Health, headed by the Director of the Office of the Minister of Health, Mr. Tariq Noah, and the membership of the Director of the Quality Department in the Ministry, a member of the Medical Advisory Committee, Mr. Muhammad Al-Jarari, the Director of the Primary Health Care Department in the Ministry, and a member of the committee The medical advisor, Mr. Hussein Al-Awami, is preparing to send and deliver the preventive supplies to confront the Corona virus.

The committee assigned by the Ministry of Health also invites all heads of the executive medical committees in the municipalities to send their delegates to pick up, starting tomorrow, Tuesday, December 8, 2020, for Covid 19 stores at the central pharmacy, Benghazi.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more cities within one or more countries

description:
In Libya on April 21, 2020, "The Deputy Foreign Minister of the internationally recognized Libyan government based in Tripoli, Mahmoud Al-Tilisi, said yesterday that the committee formed to repatriate Libyans stranded abroad as a result of border closures to mitigate the spread of the Coronavirus (Covid-19) had started the repatriation process."

"committee began its work by reaching out to Libyan consulates and heads of missions and embassies abroad to provide the necessary health care as well as accommodation and subsistence services for stranded citizens."

"work of the committee is divided into two phases. The first phase of this process includes the provision of housing for quarantine and health care and subsistence services. The second phase includes real-time PCR (polymerise chain reaction) detection procedures, as well as quarantine procedures."
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: Flights were suspended to and from the city Misaratah with the exception of emergency or cargo flights. Update: All flights to resume normally from around the world starting January 1, 2021. UPDATE: Add an end date and add an update on the travel ban because starting May 5, Misrata Airport is open to repatriation flights to and from Istanbul International Airport. Flights will resume at Misurata’s Misrata International Airport on 1 January (Libya Express, 31.12.2020). Libya, Tunisia: Update: Borders between countries to reopen from 14 November; flights to resume with COVID-19 restrictions in place (North Africa Post, 13.11.2020). Flights to all airports in southern region resume (Xinhua, 09.11.2020). Flights resume between Tripoli’s Mitiga International Airport and Benghazi’s Benina International Airport (Andalou Agency,16.10.2020).

description:
The Libyan Interior Ministry's Coronavirus task force announced a lockdown during the Eid Al-Fitr days. 

The Interior Ministry urged the residents not to go out except for necessities and to abide by cooperation with the relevant authorities to preserve their safety, instructing security apparatuses to fine and take legal procedures against the violators. Libya will see 24-hour lockdown on the three days of Eid Al-Fitr from Sunday to Tuesday.

description: On March 28, 2020, Libya "issued a decision to release 466 inmates from prisons in Tripoli controlled by the Justice Ministry, in order to reduce overcrowding. The list is to include pretrial detainees as well as detainees who meet the rules for conditional release". This was done by the Justice Ministry of the Government of  National Accord (GNA), "one of two competing authorities in Libya".
type_text: Release inmates "who are arbitrarily detained, and consider releasing pre-trial prisoners, and in particular, women, children, persons with disabilities, migrants and refugees"

description: Libya, November 16: The Minister of Health of the Libyan government, Dr. Saad Akoub, issued several directives to health facilities in the country, which the Ministry of Health assumes at the national level to organize the work of the Libyan health sector in light of the current crisis and to meet all challenges, the most important of which are: Organizing work in the Libyan health sector, where the Minister of Health stressed in his directives to all public hospital directors, the educational, rural and medical centers in the municipalities need to oblige consultants and specialists, each according to his specialization, to pass on patients and inmates to hospital departments on a daily basis and to monitor their health conditions.
date_end_spec: The policy has an unlimited time span (e.g. recommendation to wash one's hands; passing of a legal bill)
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services
institution_cat: No information in the policy about whether the government service is considered essential or non-essential
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
Sports events were canceled in addition to the closure of wedding halls, educational institutions, and smoking cafes for two weeks starting on March 16th, 2020.

On March 22, this was extended to also include funerals.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description: The city Misrata, Libya, has called upon its residents to not gather unless necessary.
target_geog_level: One or more cities within one or more countries
